inference:
The area of square ABCD is $2^2 = 4$ square cm.
The area of sector DAEC is $\frac{1}{4}\pi (2^2) = \pi$.
The area of sector DBFC is also $\frac{1}{4}\pi (2^2) = \pi$.
The area of sector DAEC = $\frac{1}{4}\pi (2^2) = \pi$.
The area of sector DBFC = $\frac{1}{4}\pi (2^2) = \pi$.
The area of region II is part of the area of sector $DBFC$ which is $\pi$ minus the area of the triangle formed by the radii of circle B and the sides of the square.
The area of triangle DBF is $\frac{1}{2}(2)(2) = 2$.
The area of region II is $\pi - 2$.
The area of region III is part of the area of sector $DAEC$.
The area of triangle DEC is $\frac{1}{2}(2)(2) = 2$.
The area of region III is $\pi - 2$.
The combined area of regions II and III is $(\pi-2) + (\pi - 2) = 2\pi - 4$.
$2\pi - 4 \approx 2(3.14159) - 4 \approx 6.28318 - 4 = 2.28318$.
Rounding to the nearest tenth, the combined area is approximately 2.3 square cm.

Final Answer: $\boxed{2.3}$
ground_truth: Regions I, II, and III combine to form a sector of a circle whose central angle measures 90 degrees.  Therefore, the area of this sector is $\frac{90}{360}\pi(\text{radius})^2=\frac{1}{4}\pi(2)^2=\pi$ square centimeters.  Also, regions I and II combine to form an isosceles right triangle whose area is $\frac{1}{2}(\text{base})(\text{height})=\frac{1}{2}(AB)(BC)=\frac{1}{2}(2)(2)=2$ square centimeters.  Subtracting these two areas, we find that the area of region III is $\pi-2$ square centimeters.  Since region II is congruent to region III, the combined area of region II and region III is $2(\pi-2)=2\pi-4\approx \boxed{2.3}$ square centimeters.

inference:
Let the square be ABCD with side length 2 cm. The area of the square is $2^2 = 4$ cm$^2$.
The circle has a radius of 2 cm.
The area of each sector DAEC and DBFC is $\frac{1}{4}$ of the area of the circle with radius 2 cm, which is $\frac{1}{4} \pi (2^2) = \pi$ cm$^2$.
The area of triangle DAB is $\frac{1}{2}(2)(2) = 2$ cm$^2$.
Region II is the area of sector DBFC minus the area of triangle DBF.
Area of region II = $\pi - 2$ cm$^2$.
Region III is the area of sector DAEC minus the area of triangle DEC.
Area of region III = $\pi - 2$ cm$^2$.
The combined area of regions II and III is $2(\pi - 2) = 2\pi - 4$ cm$^2$.
$2\pi - 4 \approx 2(3.14159) - 4 \approx 6.28318 - 4 = 2.28318$ cm$^2$.
Rounding to the nearest tenth, the combined area is approximately 2.3 cm$^2$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{2.3}$
ground_truth: Regions I, II, and III combine to form a sector of a circle whose central angle measures 90 degrees.  Therefore, the area of this sector is $\frac{90}{360}\pi(\text{radius})^2=\frac{1}{4}\pi(2)^2=\pi$ square centimeters.  Also, regions I and II combine to form an isosceles right triangle whose area is $\frac{1}{2}(\text{base})(\text{height})=\frac{1}{2}(AB)(BC)=\frac{1}{2}(2)(2)=2$ square centimeters.  Subtracting these two areas, we find that the area of region III is $\pi-2$ square centimeters.  Since region II is congruent to region III, the combined area of region II and region III is $2(\pi-2)=2\pi-4\approx \boxed{2.3}$ square centimeters.
